column2: [Illustration: Young girl sitting on tree trunk; a small bird is perched on her left hand; a small bottle is fastened to her belt.]

column2: Once upon a time a wicked nobleman rose in rebellion against his rightful king, and taking the royal forces by surprise, defeated them and seized the kingdom.
column3: Once upon a time a wicked nobleman rose in rebellion against his rightful king, and taking the royal forces by surprise, defeated them and seized the kingdom.

column2: The dethroned King, who had been severely wounded in battle, was cast in prison, where he soon died; but his widow, the Queen, managed to escape from the palace before the usurper could lay hands upon her.
column3: The dethroned King, who had been severely wounded in battle, was cast in prison, where he soon died; but his widow, the Queen, managed to escape from the palace before the usurper could lay hands upon her.

column2: Into the dark forest which lay behind the palace ran the Queen, holding her baby daughter in her arms.
column3: Into the dark forest which lay behind the palace ran the Queen, holding her baby daughter in her arms.

column2: It was winter time, and a heavy snow had hidden the foot-paths and the roads.
column3: It was winter time, and a heavy snow had hidden the foot paths and the roads.

column2: Presently the Queen realized that she was lost.
column3: Presently the Queen realized that she was lost.

column2: All afternoon, however, she trudged bravely on through the silence and the cold, her heart sinking as mile after mile revealed no sign of a house or a shelter.
column3: All afternoon, however, she trudged bravely on through the silence and the cold, her heart sinking as mile after mile revealed no sign of a house or a shelter.

column2: But late in the afternoon, when the red shield of the sun could scarcely be seen through the tangle of the wild wood-branches, she perceived a light coming from a little grove of cedars by the shore of a frozen lake.
column3: But late in the afternoon, when the red shield of the sun could scarcely be seen through the tangle of the wild wood branches, she perceived a light coming from a little grove of cedars by the shore of a frozen lake.

column2: The Queen made her way toward this light, and discovered a little thatched hut in the silent wood; it was the house of one of the dwarfs of the forest.
column3: The Queen made her way toward this light, and discovered a little thatched hut in the silent wood; it was the house of one of the dwarfs of the forest.

column2: The dwarf took pity on the Queen, but his efforts were vain, for the poor woman was so weak and exhausted that she died without telling the dwarf anything about herself or the child she carried.
column3: The dwarf took pity on the Queen, but his efforts were vain, for the poor woman was so weak and exhausted that she died without telling the dwarf anything about herself or the child she carried.

column2: So the little dwarf, who was a good, kind old fellow, brought the little girl up as if she were his own child.
column3: So the little dwarf, who was a good, kind old fellow, brought the little girl up as if she were his own child.

column2: His brother, the dwarf of the mountain, made her the prettiest red-leather shoes, and his cousins, the dwarfs of the pines, made the little girl dresses from cloth woven on fairy looms.
column3: His brother, the dwarf of the mountain, made her the prettiest red leather shoes, and his cousins, the dwarfs of the pines, made the little girl dresses from cloth woven on fairy looms.

column2: Now, on the night her mother brought her to the hut, the little girl was wearing a golden heart-shaped locket, with a crown and the letter M upon it in diamonds.
column3: Now, on the night her mother brought her to the hut, the little girl was wearing a golden heart shaped locket, with a crown and the letter M upon it in diamonds.

column2: So the dwarf called the little girl Marianna.
column3: So the dwarf called the little girl Marianna.

column2: Seventeen years passed, and Marianna grew to be quite the loveliest lass in all the world.
column3: Seventeen years passed, and Marianna grew to be quite the loveliest lass in all the world.

column2: Her hair was as black as the raven's wing, her eyes were as blue as the midsummer sea, and her skin was fair as the petal of a rose.
column3: Her hair was as black as the raven's wing, her eyes were as blue as the midsummer sea, and her skin was fair as the petal of a rose.

column2: One spring morning a little yellow bird flew into the cedar grove, and gave the dwarf a letter which it held in its beak.
column3: One spring morning a little yellow bird flew into the cedar grove, and gave the dwarf a letter which it held in its beak.

column2: The dwarf read the letter, and said to Marianna, "Little Marianna, the Emperor of the Elves has bidden me come to the great assembly of the dwarfs which is to be held next year on the Golden Mountain.

column2: I can not take you with me, dear child, for it is forbidden on pain of death to bring mortals to the assembly, nor can I leave you here in this lonely wood."

column3: Through cities and towns went lovely Marianna, bringing good cheer to the helpless and the sick, and curing all who came to her, rich and poor, with the wonderful water of healing.

column3: This pleasant land, unknown to Marianna, was part of her father's kingdom, and she was really its queen because her father had been the last rightful king.

column3: Immediately the sky grew black, the lightning crashed, and there arose a terrible, howling wind.

column2: Three giant gusts drove fiercely by, the first one blowing the King and the magician head-over-heels over the precipice, the second carrying away the soldiers, and the third the rascally favorites.
column3: Three giant gusts drove fiercely by, the first one blowing the King and the magician head over heels over the precipice, the second carrying away the soldiers, and the third the rascally favorites.

column2: When the sky cleared, only the dwarf, Marianna, and Desire were left of the company.
column3: When the sky cleared, only the dwarf, Marianna, and Desire were left of the company.

column2: Marianna, said the little dwarf, "the Emperor of the Elves has told me all your history, and it is thanks to him that I have returned in time, with the storm at my heels.
column3: Marianna, said the little dwarf, "the Emperor of the Elves has told me all your history, and it is thanks to him that I have returned in time, with the storm at my heels.

column2: You, Marianna, are the rightful Queen of this country."
column3: You, Marianna, are the rightful Queen of this country."

column2: Dear Queen, said the honest and gallant Desire, "let me be the first of your subjects to salute you." And he knelt before her, and humbly kissed her hand.
column3: Dear Queen, said the honest and gallant Desire, "let me be the first of your subjects to salute you." And he knelt before her, and humbly kissed her hand.

column2: Nay, Prince, said the young Queen, answering the adoring look in her lover's eyes, "your father took the kingdom; if I were you, I should take the Queen."
column3: Nay, Prince, said the young Queen, answering the adoring look in her lover's eyes, "your father took the kingdom; if I were you, I should take the Queen."

column2: Which was a bit forward, of course, but nobody minded that very much in those fairy times.
column3: Which was a bit forward, of course, but nobody minded that very much in those fairy times.

column2: So Desire and Marianna were married, and lived happily ever after.
column3: So Desire and Marianna were married, and lived happily ever after.

column2: The yellow bird went to the wedding, and when the ceremony was over rose singing into the air, and flew joyously home to the land of the Elves.
column3: The yellow bird went to the wedding, and when the ceremony was over rose singing into the air, and flew joyously home to the land of the Elves.
